p: The case fatality rate (CFR) for all reported cases of SARS in pregnancy (n = 17) was 15% ( 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37), and was higher among pregnant women. Mechanical ventilation was required three times more often in pregnant versus nonpregnant women. A case control study comparing ten pregnant to 40 nonpregnant women affected by SARS reported a 60% intensive care unit admission rate and a 40% case fatality rate in the pregnant group compared with only an 18% and 0% rate in the nonpregnant group ( 32).
